titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Louis H. Pollak Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Matthew Gorham, Christine Connolly, and Sheilah Robinson

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 6, 2019 at 08:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection comprises the papers of attorney, legal scholar, and United States Circuit Court judge, Louis H. Pollak. The papers consist of correspondence and subject files documenting myriad aspects of his life and career, including his tenure as a professor and Dean at Yale Law School.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Louis Heilprin Pollak, a United States District Court judge and former dean of the Yale and University of Pennyslvania Law Schools, was born on December 7, 1922, in New York City. He received his undergraduate degree from Harvard University in 1943, and after serving in the United States Army, received his law degree from Yale. After graduating from law school, Pollak worked as a clerk for Justice Wiley B. Rutledge of the United States Supreme Court from 1948 to 1949, and thereafter accepted a position at the law firm, Paul, Weiss, Wharton & Garrison (known in 2013 as Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison). It was during his tenure at this firm that Pollak was recruited by Thurgood Marshall to serve as a volunteer for the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, which afforded him the opportunity to contribute significantly to several landmark civil rights cases.

Pollak was a member of the legal team that represented the plaintiffs in Brown v. Board of Education , the 1954 Supreme Court case that overturned legal segregation in American public schools. In 1965, he argued before the Supreme Court in the Abernathy v. Alabama case, which resulted in the reversal of criminal convictions of Freedom Riders who had campaigned to desegregate buses and bus stations in the South. Pollak also argued before the Supreme Court on behalf of the plaintiffs in McLaughlin v. Florida , in which the court unanimously repealed a law banning the cohabitation of people of different races.

Pollak joined the Yale Law School faculty in 1955 and was appointed dean in 1965, a position he held until 1970. In 1974, he joined the faculty of the University of Pennsylvania Law School and was named dean the following year. President Jimmy Carter appointed Pollak to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania in 1978. During his 36-year tenure as a judge, Pollak was known as a staunch advocate of defendents' rights. In 1992, Pollak became a senior judge in semi-retirement, and in addition to his district court duties, sat by designation regularly with the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, and also often with the Ninth Circuit. Louis H. Pollak died on May 8, 2012, and at the time of his death, was survived by his wife, Katherine Weiss Pollak, five daughters, and seven grandchildren.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Louis H. Pollak Papers (MS 1989). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in four series: I. Alphabetical correspondence, 1965-2012; II. Chronological correspondence, 1964-2004; Series III. Subject files, 1948-2004; IV. Supreme Court justice files, 1989-2012.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research with the exception of Box 60, which contains files of correspondence with current and former Justices of the United States Supreme Court. Correspondence with any current or former Justice of the United States Supreme Court shall remain closed to all research until the death of that Justice or former Justice.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection whether such works are at Yale or physically located elsewhere in the world. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection comprises the papers of attorney, legal scholar, and United States Circuit Court judge, Louis H. Pollak. The papers consist of correspondence and subject files documenting myriad aspects of his life and career, including his tenure as professor and dean at Yale Law School.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of both incoming and outgoing correspondence, the bulk of which dates from the early 1980s through 2012, with a few items dating from the mid-1960s and the 1970s. The correspondence primarily concerns Pollak's scholarly work and professional engagement, through writing, speaking engagements, and discussions with colleagues about important legal issues of the day. There is also some correspondence pertaining to social matters. Correspondents of note include Robert Bork and William J. Brennan, Jr.

did.unittitle: Hershman Barbara Anne and Walter R. Felton (wedding)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence that mostly spans the earlier period of Louis Pollak's career as an attorney, legal scholar, and judge. Like the alphabetical correspondence series, these materials mostly pertain to Pollak's scholarly work and professional engagement, through writing, speaking engagements, and discussions with colleagues about important legal issues of the day, and also includes a substantial body of correspondence from the mid-to-late 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes an assortment of materials related to Louis Pollak's professional life, research interests, and legal scholarship. Of note are files pertaining to Abernathy v. Alabama , a key civil rights lawsuit that Pollak argued before the United States Supreme Court.

scopecontent.p: Material includes letters to editors and statements regarding public matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence with and other documents relating to several current and former justices of the United States Supreme Court.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Correspondence with any current or former Justice of the United States Supreme Court shall remain closed to all research until the death of that Justice or former Justice.

Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.
